category.name: BiBiServ
category.categoryDescription: Welcome to BiBiserv. The Bielefeld University Bioinformatics Server.

categoryRepresentation.title: BiBiServ - Bielefeld University Bioinformatics Server
categoryRepresentation.customContent: The Bielefeld Bioinformatics Server (BiBiServ) is a relatively small unit of the Institute for Bioinformatics (IFB) within the Center for Biotechnology (CeBiTec) dedicated to providing persistent service to the community by hosting bioinformatics tools which emerge from the research of the Bielefeld groups and their direct collaborators.

category.name: Tools
category.categoryDescription: The BiBiServ Tool section currently offers bioinformatics tools for a large variety of tasks

categoryRepresentation.title: BiBiServ Tool Section
categoryRepresentation.customContent: As some analyses can take a long time - sometimes over several hours - BiBiServ provides two different result delivery mechanisms. Results of short analyses (less than 5 minutes compute time) are shown immediately in the browser. For longer analyses (maximum of one day compute time) the result is stored on a temporary web-site and the corresponding URL is sent to the user via E-mail. BiBiServ runs in a UNIX environment. The data stored locally can be accessed only by the BiBiServ administrators. The result of a calculation is stored temporarily for three days and deleted afterwards. We do not offer encrypted submissions.

runnableItem.name: RNAfold
runnableItem.shortDescription: RNAfold calculates secondary structures of RNAs

description.p: BiBiServ offers a Webservice interface for RNA folding and sequence design using the program RNAfold from the Vienna package.

runnableItem.toolTipText: Calculation of secondary structures of RNAs

param.name: folding temparature
param.shortDescription: Rescale energy parameters to a folding temperature of temp C. Default is 37C.
param.description: No decription yet,see shortDescription for a short description.

function.name: Simple Computation
function.shortDescription: shape computation with optional temperature variable

description.p: This function computes a simple MFE Structure, optionally using the environment temperature to modify the resulting structure.

runnableItem.name: RNAshapes
runnableItem.shortDescription: RNAshapes: an integrated RNA analysis package based on abstract shapes
RNAshapes: ein integriertes RNA-Analysepaket, welches auf abstrakten `shapes` basiert.
runnableItem.description: RNAshapes offers three RNA analysis tools in one single software package: computation of a small set of representative structures of different shapes, computation of shape probabilities, and comparative prediction of consensus structures.
runnableItem.customContent:
RNAshapes Current version: RNAshapes 2.1.5 (Apr. 15. 2008)
RNA shape abstraction maps structures to a tree-like domain of shapes, retaining adjacency and nesting of structural features, but disregarding helix lengths. Shape abstraction integrates well with dynamic programming algorithms, and hence it can be applied during structure prediction rather than afterwards. This avoids exponential explosion and can still give us a non-heuristic and complete account of properties of the molecule`s folding space. RNAshapes offers three powerful RNA analysis tools in one single software package:
Computation of a small set of representative structures of different shapes, complete in a well-defined sense.
Computation of accumulated shape probabilities.
Comparative prediction of consensus structures, as an alternative to the over-expensive Sankoff Algorithm.
RNAshapes is available as C source code and compiled binaries for Unix, Mac OS X and Microsoft Windows. See download section.
RNAshapes can also be used online (submission section). This also links to a website that allows to study the combinatorics of shapes. P. Steffen, B. Voß, M. Rehmsmeier, J. Reeder, and R. Giegerich. RNAshapes: an integrated RNA analysis package based on abstract shapes. Bioinformatics, 22(4), 2006.

input.name: FASTA
input.description: RNAsequence in FASTA format. FASTA is a text based format ...

output.name: DotBracket
output.shortDescription: RNA secondary structure in DotBracket notation.
output.description: RNA secondary structure in DotBracket notation. DotBracket is a text based format ...

param.name: prob_number
param.shortDescription: sets the maximum numbers of probabilities to calculate
param.description: sets the maximum numbers of probabilities to calculate

param.name: match_shape
param.shortDescription: declare a shape that all structures have to match
param.description: shape declared using the symbols `[`, `]` and `_`. max 1000 chars sets a shape, that all structures have to match

enumParam.name: energy_mode
enumParam.description: Sets the energy range either as percentage value of the minimum free energy (% of mfe) or as the difference to the minimum free energy for the sequence (kcal/mol).

function.name: RNAshapes_shape_folding
function.description: Shape folding: RNA folding based on abstract shapes. This is the standard mode of operation when no other options are given. It calculates the shapes and the corresponding shreps based on free energy minimization.

function.name: Supoptimal_Shape_Folding
function.description: Suboptimal shape folding: Complete suboptimal folding of RNA. This mode uses a non-ambiguous grammar that also handles dangling bases of multiloop components in a non-ambiguous way.

function.name: Sampling
function.description: Sampling: Probabilistic sampling based on partition function. This mode combines stochastic sampling with a-posteriori shape abstraction. A sample from the structure space holds M structures together with their shapes, on which classification is performed. The probability of a shape can then be approximated by its frequency in the sample. Sequences up to a length of around 1500 can be handled with this mode. In our experience, 1000 iterations are sufficient to achieve reasonable results for shapes with high probability.

function.name: Consensus_Shapes
function.description: Consensus shapes: For a family of RNA sequences, this method independently enumerates the near-optimal abstract shape space, and predicts as the consensus an abstract shape common to all sequences. For each sequence, it delivers the thermodynamically best structure which has this common shape. Since the shape space is much smaller than the structure space, and identification of common shapes can be done in linear time (in the number of shapes considered), the method is essentially linear in the number of sequences.

manual.introductoryText: This manual page gives a detailed description of all parameters providing by all functions implemented in the webinterface.

runnableItem.name: ClustalW
runnableItem.shortDescription: ClustalW is a general purpose multiple sequence alignment program for DNA or proteins.
runnableItem.description: ClustalW is a general purpose multiple sequence alignment program for DNA or proteins. It produces biologically meaningful multiple sequence alignments of divergent sequences. It calculates the best match for the selected sequences, and lines them up so that the identities, similarities and differences can be seen. BiBiServ offers a Webservice Interface and an HTML interface for running ClustalW online in a browser.
runnableItem.keywords: Alignment DNA Proteins Amino Cremoved problems with execution string acids Multiple Sequences Webservice Webform

article.author: J. D. Thompson, D. G. Higgins and T. J. Gibson
article.title: CLUSTAL W: improving the sensitivity of progressive multiple sequence alignment through sequence weighting, position-specific gap penalties and weight matrix choice
article.journal: Nucleic Acids Research, Oxford University Press

input.name: FASTA
input.description: Sequences in FASTA-Format consist of at least two lines. The first line is a header that starts with ">" and the ID of the sequence. The second line and all eventually following lines carry the sequence informtaion.

Sequenzen in FASTA-Format bestehen aus mindestens zwei Zeilen.Die erste Zeile, der sogenannte "Header" startet mit einem ">" und darauffolgend der ID der Sequenz. Die zweite und alle weiteren Zeilen, die nicht mit einem ">" starten enthalten dann die Sequenzinformationen.

output.name: FASTA
output.description: Sequences in FASTA-Format consist of at least two lines. The first line is a header that starts with ">" and the ID of the sequence. The second line and all eventually following lines carry the sequence informtaion.

param.name: Gap opening Penalty
param.shortDescription: Opening gaps in the sequence alignment are avoided if the gap extension value is set to a higher value.
param.description: Opening gaps in the sequence alignment are avoided if the gap extension value is set to a higher value.

param.name: Gap extension Penalty
param.shortDescription: Long gaps in the sequence alignment are avoided if the gap extension value is set to a higher value.
param.description: Long gaps in the sequence alignment are avoided if the gap extension value is set to a higher value

enumParam.name: Protein weight Matrix
enumParam.shortDescription: Scoring Matrix that keeps propabilities for an exchange of one protein against anaother according to evolutionary time.
enumParam.description: Scoring Matrix that keeps propabilities for an exchange of one protein against anaother according to evolutionary time. Scoring matrices appear in all analysis involving sequence comparison. The choice of matrix can strongly influence the outcome of the analysis. Scoring matrices implicitly represent a particular theory of evolution. Understanding theories underlying a given scoring matrix can aid in making proper choice. The protein weight matrix offers a choice of weight matrices. The default for proteins is the PAM series derived by Gonnet and colleagues. Different matrices work differently at each evolutionary distance. You can choose between the following Matrices:

manual.introductoryText: The sensitivity of the commonly used progressive multiple sequence alignment method has been greatly improved for the alignment of divergent protein sequences. Firstly, individual weights are assigned to each sequence in a partial alignment in order to down-weight near-duplicate sequences and up-weight the most divergent ones. Secondly, amino acid substitution matrices are varied at different alignment stages according to the divergence of the sequences to be aligned. Thirdly, residue-specific gap penalties and locally reduced gap penalties in hydrophilic regions encourage new gaps in potential loop regions rather than regular secondary structure. Fourthly, positions in early alignments where gaps have been opened receive locally reduced gap penalties to encourage the opening up of new gaps at these positions. These modifications are incorporated into the program, CLUSTAL W which is freely available.

categoryRepresentation.customContent: Bioinformatics is a young and dynmaic field. The integration of knowledge from biology and computer science requires a significant educational effort. Our Distance Education and Training Department ...

category.name: Dynamic Programming
category.categoryDescription: Dynamic programming is a predominant programming technique in biosequence analysis. Algebraic Dynamic Programming (ADP) is a new method to design and implement, tune, test and teach Dynamic Programming algorithms.

item.name: Algebraic Dynamic Programming (ADP)
item.shortDescription: Algebraic Dynamic Programming (ADP) is a new method to design ,implement, tune, test amd teach Dynamic Programming algorithms.
item.description: Algebraic Dynamic Programming (ADP) is a new method to design ,implement, tune, test amd teach Dynamic Programming algorithms. Compared to the traditional style, ADP provides a much higher level of abstarction, helping to solve more sophisticated problems with better chances of success.

linkedFile.name: DP online course
linkedFile.shortDescription: Dynamic Programming in Bioinformatics - Online course

item.name: SADR
item.description: A WWW-based practical course on Sequence Analysis with Distributed Resources. This course has been available since 1998. A previous version has been translated into several languages and was regularly offered at various locations. So much for history -- the course has been updated and completely remodelled in 2005 and 2009.

categoryRepresentation.title: BiBiServ Administration
categoryRepresentation.customContent: The BiBiServ (Bielefeld BioInformatics Service) is a unit of the IfB (Institute for Bioinformatics) inside the CeBiTec (Center for Biotechnology) at Bielefeld University.The Service is operational since 1996 and provides a multitude of bioinformatical tools for users worldwide via the Bielefeld BioInformatics Server. The service group consists of several curators responsible for the smooth operation, the continuous modernisation and improvement of the server as well as the handling of user requests.

microhtml:ul.microhtml:li: Availbility:All tools are available online for free, both to academic and commercial users. Some of the software tools are distributed also or only for local installation. In the latter case commercial users may have to pay a licence fee.
Credits:If you use BiBiServ tools for your research and publich your results, we request that you cite the BiBiServ URL as well as reference article indicated with each tool individually

Tool release:New tools officially appear on BiBiServ as soon as corresponding publciations explaining their purpose and underlying algorithm appear. Unofficially (i.e. witout a hotlink from the main web-site) they may appear earlier, to facilitate cooperation or evaluation by external researchers.

Tool selection:While some tools have thousands of users per month, others less than hundred, and some perhaps only ten, the criterion of persistence on BiBiServ is not popularity, but scientific value. Tools disappear from BiBiServ when their purpose has become obsolete (because scientific questions or laboratory techniques have changed), or when a better tool for the same purpose becomes available elsewhere.

Confidentiality:BiBiServ runs in a UNIX environment. The data stored locally can be accessed only by the BiBiServ administrators. The result of a calculation is stored temporarily for three days and deleted afterwards. We do not offer encrypted submissions.

customContent.microhtml:strong: Attention: These policies copied from the old/current server. Policies of the new BiBiServ 2.0 may be (slightly) different.

item.name: Team
item.description: All current and past BiBiServ curators
item.customContent:
BiBiServ has no permanent staff dedicated to development of tools. Students in our local bioinformatics curriculum do project works and diploma theses. PhD students as well as postdocs contribute software or educational material from their research and their teaching. Sometimes we also decide to serve software developed by collaborators of our group. A small group of curators takes care that BiBiServ runs reliably and consistently.
If you have any comments, suggestions or technical problems, please send email to the server curators at bibi-help(at)techfak.uni-bielefeld.de. The BiBiServ curators are:
Alexander Sczyrba (group leader - currently on leave at JGI)
Daniel Hagemeier (server technology)
Sven Hartmeier (server technology)
Susanne Konermann (design / educational media)
Jan Krüger (server technology - temporary group leader)
Richard Madsack (graduate assistant)
Armin Töpfer (student assistant) Previous members:
Bastian Meyer
Christian Peters
Kai Löwenthal (educational media)
Alexander Kaiser
Jan Reinkensmeier
Henning Mersch (server technology)
Georg Sauthoff
Nan Zhang
Jörn Clausen (educational media)
Johannes Huth
Elke Wohlleben
Stefan Kurtz
Michael Höhl
Kai Runte
Dirk Evers
Chris Schleiermacher>

microhtml:ul.microhtml:li: The Institute of Genome Research in the Biology Department, directed by Prof. Dr. A. Puehler and Prof. Dr. B. Weisshaar, helps us to find out what kind of software support the practicing biologists really need.
The Bioinformatics Resource Facility (BRF), directed by Dr. A. Goessmann, provides access to databases and computing resources.
The Ph.D. students at our International Graduate School in Bioinformatics and Genome Research contribute to our tool supply in manifold ways.
